error.signature: Could not apply <hash>... Resolve all conflicts manually, then run git rebase --continue
error.regex: (?:Could not apply [0-9a-f]+|CONFLICT.*(?:rebase|cherry-pick)|git rebase --(?:continue|abort|skip)|interactive rebase in progress)

common_contexts: Cleaning up feature branch before merge

verdict.summary: Interactive rebase replays commits one by one onto a new base. When a commit conflicts with the new context, git stops and asks you to resolve manually. Unlike a simple merge conflict, you may face multiple rounds of conflicts (one per conflicting commit). The todo file in .git/rebase-merge/ controls which commits are replayed.

dead_ends.action: Using git merge instead of resolving the rebase conflict
dead_ends.why_fails: You cannot mix merge and rebase operations. Running 'git merge' while a rebase is in progress creates an inconsistent state. You must either resolve the current conflict and 'git rebase --continue', or abort entirely with 'git rebase --abort'.

dead_ends.action: Editing .git/rebase-merge/git-rebase-todo manually after rebase has started
dead_ends.why_fails: The todo file can only be safely edited during the initial editor prompt of git rebase -i. Once rebase has started replaying commits, modifying the todo file directly leads to unpredictable behavior. If you need to change the plan, abort and restart the interactive rebase.

dead_ends.action: Running git rebase --skip without understanding what commit is being skipped
dead_ends.why_fails: --skip permanently drops the current commit from the rebased history. If you skip a commit that contains important changes (not just conflict noise), those changes are lost from the branch. Always check 'git log --oneline REBASE_HEAD' or 'git show REBASE_HEAD' before skipping.

workarounds.action: Resolve conflicts commit by commit with git rebase --continue
workarounds.how: For each conflicting commit: 1) Open conflicted files and resolve the markers (<<<< ==== >>>>). 2) Stage resolved files with 'git add <file>'. 3) Run 'git rebase --continue' to proceed to the next commit. Repeat until all commits are replayed. Use 'git diff' and 'git status' to verify resolution at each step.

workarounds.action: Abort and retry with a different rebase strategy
workarounds.how: Run 'git rebase --abort' to return to the state before rebase started. Then try alternative approaches: 1) Squash locally first with 'git reset --soft' then recommit, 2) Use 'git rebase -i --autosquash' with fixup commits, 3) Rebase fewer commits at a time to isolate conflicts.
workarounds.condition: When conflicts are too complex to resolve commit-by-commit

workarounds.action: Use git rerere to auto-resolve recurring conflicts
workarounds.how: Enable with 'git config --global rerere.enabled true'. Git records how you resolve conflicts and auto-applies the same resolution if the same conflict appears again. Particularly useful for long-running feature branches that are rebased repeatedly against main.
workarounds.tradeoff: Only helps with identical conflict patterns; initial resolution still manual

leads_to.condition: Multiple commits in interactive rebase can each produce separate conflicts

preceded_by.condition: Developer tries to rebase diverged branch onto upstream

frequently_confused_with.distinction: rebase-conflict covers simple non-interactive rebase. Interactive rebase has additional complexity from the todo list (pick, squash, edit, reword) and multi-step conflict resolution.
cherry-pick applies a single commit; interactive rebase replays multiple commits sequentially and can reorder, squash, or edit them.
